newsitem.title: USA: IMM currency futures end lower, mark hits new low.
newsitem.headline: IMM currency futures end lower, mark hits new low.

text.p: IMM currency futures finished erratic pit trading lower, but most units ended above the day's price troughs.
Traders tied the final leg back down in March sterling to small sales in thin trading that exaggerated price moves.
"It just followed everything else," said one floor broker of sterling's renewed decline during the last 30 minutes. "Everybody was getting out of positions, it was thin and a 50-lot could move it."
Price boards showed estimated volume in March sterling at about 8,000 contracts Tuesday.
Sterling traders said they also continued to wait for Wednesday's quarterly Bank of England inflation report as well as signs of a solid date for the next U.K. election.
The day's featured move occurred near midday, when March marks skidded abruptly to a new contract low at $0.5960 and nearly a $0.0100 loss as the morning's erosion briefly accelerated.

The quick selloff, which found fuel from sellstops, stemmed from a news wire story that said sources close to the German finance ministry and Bundesbank said Germany would welcome a dollar rise to 1.70-1.75 marks over time.
"That's what got it rolling," said a floor broker. "But everybody's still afraid of the central banks."
Later comments by U.S. Treasury secretary Robert Rubin were viewed as reiterations of his recent remarks and had muted impact, they added.

Rubin said that the dollar fall has corrected to a normal mode, that the strong dollar had helped keep U.S. inflation and rates low, and that the dollar should not be used as an instrument of trade policy.
"What he's saying now is nothing different than what he said at the G7," said a second broker.

Brokers said many still looked for more dollar upside soon, although uncertainty about the G7's tolerance for the extent and rapidity of the dollar's advance made them leery of predicting a further straight shot higher.

March yen ended down $0.000026 at $0.008164, marks lost $0.0073 to $0.5980, Swiss francs declined $0.0049 to $0.6989, sterling fell $0.0054 to $1.6354, Canadian dollar eased $0.0001 to $0.7400, Aussie dollar lost $0.0007 to $0.7571, Mexican peso rose $0.000075 to $0.126350. ((DerivativesDesk(312)408-8750/E-mail:derivatives@reuters.com))
